bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to H. Carter Redd, January 20, 1948

div1.p: Hench thanks Redd for seeking permission from Carter's son for Hench to borrow the Carter correspondence. Hench offers to examine all the material himself and to treat it with respect. He is especially interested in correspondence between Carter and Reed, Lazear, Welch, or Sternberg.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to H. Carter Redd, January 20, 1948
div1.opener:
Y. F.
January 20, 1948
Mr. H. Carter Redd
1104 Travelers Building
Richmond, Virginia
My dear Mr. Redd:
div1.p:
How kind of you to write Doctor Carter in my behalf. I can
assure you that nothing will be lost or improperly used. It will all be
returned safely by registered or insured post. You state that it might
be well for you to go through the boxes and “eliminate a lots of private
correspondence”. May I respectfully suggest that you refrain from destroying
anything. Although I am fundamentally interested in Doctor Carter's rela-
tionship to Reed and Lazear and in the story of yellow fever, others may
come along who will wish to write a more comprehensive story of Doctor
Carter's life. In such event, his private correspondence would be ab-
solutely invaluable. Even letters written by him to unimportant people
about relatively unimportant matters are often invaluable to biographers
and historians, as they give dates which show where Doctor Carter was at
such and such a time. Often this is the only way the whereabouts of an
important person could ever be established. Furthermore, such personal
letters can give subtle evidence as to the character, humor and philosophy
of a man and I beg of you that for the sake of those interested in Doctor
Carter, not to destroy any of this material.

Should you have the time to go through the material, I should be
of course pleased to receive whatever you wish to send me. If, however, you
or Doctor Carter do not have time to do this and if, based purely on my
position and reputation, you are willing to trust me, I should be glad to
have the material shipped to me in toto, insured, and I will certainly find
time in my hours away from work, to go through the material with respectful
care. Please kindly permit me to see what concerns yellow fever and also
malaria.

I have no doubt that the material you are procuring for me will
be absolutely invaluable and will show as has never been done before the
exact part Doctor Carter took in helping Lazear and Reed to find the solu-
tion to the conquest of yellow fever. I am extremely anxious to see the
letter which Reed sent to Doctor Carter. I am particularly eager to know
if there is any correspondence between Doctor Carter and Lazear, Welch, or
Sternberg. Thank you very much indeed for your splendid cooperation. I
am sending a carbon of this to you in case you wish to forward it to Doctor
Carter.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:Alc
